text: After Alicia leaves, the tavern becomes unnaturally quiet. Only the fire in the hearth, the drip of melting snow, and my own breathing remain.
I try to follow her instructions—bolt the door, tend to my bruised face, pretend everything is normal.
But the harder I try to act “normal,” the louder last night’s words echo in my head—“the thirty-seventh time.”
“…What is she planning to do?”
I set down the cloth and touch the short sword beneath the counter. The blade is cold—like a reminder: you’re afraid.
I tell myself: I’ll just go to the market and make sure she’s fine. Just confirm it, then come back.
I lock the door and hurry along the snow-soaked street. The market is bustling, but I can recognize her silhouette instantly—silver hair stands out too much.
I follow from a distance, not daring to get too close. The way she shops feels like she’s executing a checklist: no small talk, no hesitation, not a single wasted word.

I hide behind a row of stalls and watch her place potions, sealing talismans, and bandages into her bag one by one. When a vendor tries to raise the price, she doesn’t even look at him—and he lowers it himself.
“She looks… like a different person today.”
I’m about to step forward when I notice she’s turned toward the pine-lined stone road back to the tavern.
The wind grows colder, tree shadows swaying over the snow. I quicken my pace, about to call out to her, when I hear a dull thud beneath my feet.
The soil splits open. A stone-shelled beast crawls out, its blue-lit eyes fixed ahead—not on me, but on her.
“Damn—!”
“I told you not to stop near the tree line.”
She doesn’t turn around, as if she already knew I was behind her. Then she draws her sword—cleanly, like harvesting. A flash of silver.
The beast barely lifts off the ground before her first strike forces it back down. The second blow falls; the stone shell shatters, the blue glow extinguished.
It dissolves into black smoke and sinks back into the soil. Only a scorched ring remains on the ground.
“Why did you follow me? Didn’t trust me?”
“I… didn’t.”
She sighs, but her tone isn’t harsh. “It’s always like this. You’re just too kind.”
“Come on. Don’t stare at the scorched earth.”
